repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
			echo byteidx('aðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š', 2)	    " returns 5
			echo byteidx('aðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š', 2, 1)	" returns 1
			echo byteidx('aðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š', 3, 1)	" returns 5
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -612,17 +633,18 @@ byteidx({expr}, {nr} [, {utf16}])				*byteidx()*
 		in bytes is returned.
 		See |charidx()| and |utf16idx()| for getting the character and
 		UTF-16 index respectively from the byte index.
-		Examples: >
+		Examples: >vim
 			echo byteidx('aðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š', 2)	returns 5
 			echo byteidx('aðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š', 2, 1)	returns 1
 			echo byteidx('aðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š', 3, 1)	returns 5

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
			blob2list(0z0102.0304)	" returns [1, 2, 3, 4]
			blob2list(0z)           " returns []
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -361,39 +371,41 @@ atan({expr})							*atan()*
 		the range [-pi/2, +pi/2] radians, as a |Float|.
 		{expr} must evaluate to a |Float| or a |Number|.
 		Returns 0.0 if {expr} is not a |Float| or a |Number|.
-		Examples: >
+		Examples: >vim
 			:echo atan(100)
-<			1.560797 >
+<			1.560797 >vim
 			:echo atan(-4.01)
 <			-1.326405
 
-		Can also be used as a |method|: >
+		Can also be used as a |method|: >vim
 			Compute()->atan()
+<
 
 atan2({expr1}, {expr2})					*atan2()*
 		Return the arc tangent of {expr1} / {expr2}, measured in
 		radians, as a |Float| in the range [-pi, pi].
 		{expr1} and {expr2} must evaluate to a |Float| or a |Number|.
 		Returns 0.0 if {expr1} or {expr2} is not a |Float| or a
 		|Number|.
-		Examples: >
+		Examples: >vim
 			:echo atan2(-1, 1)
-<			-0.785398 >
+<			-0.785398 >vim
 			:echo atan2(1, -1)
 <			2.356194
 
-		Can also be used as a |method|: >
+		Can also be used as a |method|: >vim
 			Compute()->atan2(1)
+<
 
 blob2list({blob})					*blob2list()*
 		Return a List containing the number value of each byte in Blob
-		{blob}.  Examples: >
+		{blob}.  Examples: >vim
 			blob2list(0z0102.0304)	returns [1, 2, 3, 4]
 			blob2list(0z)		returns []

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
			bufname("#")		" alternate buffer name
			bufname(3)		" name of buffer 3
			bufname("%")		" name of current buffer
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -511,13 +528,13 @@ bufname([{buf}])						*bufname()*
 		with a listed buffer, that one is returned.  Next unlisted
 		buffers are searched for.
 		If the {buf} is a String, but you want to use it as a buffer
-		number, force it to be a Number by adding zero to it: >
+		number, force it to be a Number by adding zero to it: >vim
 			:echo bufname("3" + 0)
-<		Can also be used as a |method|: >
+<		Can also be used as a |method|: >vim
 			echo bufnr->bufname()
 
 <		If the buffer doesn't exist, or doesn't have a name, an empty
-		string is returned. >
+		string is returned. >vim
 			bufname("#")		alternate buffer name
 			bufname(3)		name of buffer 3
 			bufname("%")		name of current buffer

```

@@ -850,7 +876,7 @@ col({expr} [, {winid}])					*col()*
 		For the screen column position use |virtcol()|.  For the
 		character position use |charcol()|.
 		Note that only marks in the current file can be used.
-		Examples: >
+		Examples: >vim
 			col(".")		column of cursor
 			col("$")		length of cursor line plus one
 			col("'t")		column of mark t

 		expression, which is used as a String.
 		If you don't care about the file being readable you can use
 		|glob()|.

 			echo filereadable(expand('~/.vimrc'))
 			1

 list2blob({list})					*list2blob()*

-		Examples: >

 			list2blob([])		returns 0z
 <		Returns an empty Blob on error.  If one of the numbers is

-<		The same can be done (slowly) with: >

```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8081,28 +8253,30 @@ str2float({string} [, {quoted}])			*str2float()*
 		The decimal point is always '.', no matter what the locale is
 		set to.  A comma ends the number: "12,345.67" is converted to
 		12.0.  You can strip out thousands separators with
-		|substitute()|: >
+		|substitute()|: >vim
 			let f = str2float(substitute(text, ',', '', 'g'))
 <
 		Returns 0.0 if the conversion fails.
 
-		Can also be used as a |method|: >
+		Can also be used as a |method|: >vim
 			let f = text->substitute(',', '', 'g')->str2float()
+<
 
 str2list({string} [, {utf8}])				*str2list()*
 		Return a list containing the number values which represent
-		each character in String {string}.  Examples: >
+		each character in String {string}.  Examples: >vim
 			str2list(" ")		returns [32]
 			str2list("ABC")		returns [65, 66, 67]

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8081,28 +8253,30 @@ str2float({string} [, {quoted}])			*str2float()*
 		The decimal point is always '.', no matter what the locale is
 		set to.  A comma ends the number: "12,345.67" is converted to
 		12.0.  You can strip out thousands separators with
-		|substitute()|: >
+		|substitute()|: >vim
 			let f = str2float(substitute(text, ',', '', 'g'))
 <
 		Returns 0.0 if the conversion fails.
 
-		Can also be used as a |method|: >
+		Can also be used as a |method|: >vim
 			let f = text->substitute(',', '', 'g')->str2float()
+<
 
 str2list({string} [, {utf8}])				*str2list()*
 		Return a list containing the number values which represent
-		each character in String {string}.  Examples: >
+		each character in String {string}.  Examples: >vim
 			str2list(" ")		returns [32]
 			str2list("ABC")		returns [65, 66, 67]
 <		|list2str()| does the opposite.
 
 		UTF-8 encoding is always used, {utf8} option has no effect,
 		and exists only for backwards-compatibility.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
		  :echo strftime("%c")		   " Sun Apr 27 11:49:23 1997
		  :echo strftime("%Y %b %d %X")	   " 1997 Apr 27 11:53:25
		  :echo strftime("%y%m%d %T")	   " 970427 11:53:55
		  :echo strftime("%H:%M")	   " 11:55
		  :echo strftime("%c", getftime("file.c"))
						   " Show mod time of file.c.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8217,16 +8393,17 @@ strftime({format} [, {time}])				*strftime()*
 		format.  The maximum length of the result is 80 characters.
 		See also |localtime()|, |getftime()| and |strptime()|.
 		The language can be changed with the |:language| command.
-		Examples: >
+		Examples: >vim
 		  :echo strftime("%c")		   Sun Apr 27 11:49:23 1997
 		  :echo strftime("%Y %b %d %X")	   1997 Apr 27 11:53:25
 		  :echo strftime("%y%m%d %T")	   970427 11:53:55
 		  :echo strftime("%H:%M")	   11:55
 		  :echo strftime("%c", getftime("file.c"))
 						   Show mod time of file.c.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
		  :echo stridx("An Example", "Example")	     " 3
		  :echo stridx("Starting point", "Start")    " 0
		  :echo stridx("Starting point", "start")   " -1
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8237,29 +8414,30 @@ strgetchar({str}, {index})				*strgetchar()*
 		Returns -1 if {index} is invalid.
 		Also see |strcharpart()| and |strchars()|.
 
-		Can also be used as a |method|: >
+		Can also be used as a |method|: >vim
 			GetText()->strgetchar(5)
+<
 
 stridx({haystack}, {needle} [, {start}])			*stridx()*
 		The result is a Number, which gives the byte index in
 		{haystack} of the first occurrence of the String {needle}.
 		If {start} is specified, the search starts at index {start}.
-		This can be used to find a second match: >
+		This can be used to find a second match: >vim
 			:let colon1 = stridx(line, ":")
 			:let colon2 = stridx(line, ":", colon1 + 1)
 <		The search is done case-sensitive.
 		For pattern searches use |match()|.
 		-1 is returned if the {needle} does not occur in {haystack}.
 		See also |strridx()|.
-		Examples: >
+		Examples: >vim
 		  :echo stridx("An Example", "Example")	     3
 		  :echo stridx("Starting point", "Start")    0
 		  :echo stridx("Starting point", "start")   -1

@@ -9182,7 +9384,7 @@ utf16idx({string}, {idx} [, {countcc} [, {charidx}]])	*utf16idx()*
 			echo utf16idx('aaÌ¨Ìc', 6, 1)	returns 4
 			echo utf16idx('aðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š', 9)	returns -1

comment_data.body: That will break the lua->vim injection in our other docs, which I would hate to lose?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
 ((codeblock
   (language) @injection.language
   (code) @injection.content)
- (#set! injection.include-children))

comment_data.body:
Are they really worth it?

The alternative (right now) would be to have no injections.

We can re-enable this when we add lazy injections.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
 ((codeblock
   (language) @injection.language
   (code) @injection.content)
- (#set! injection.include-children))

comment_data.body:
Yes, they are really worth it. I'd rather drop the comment parser from nvim-treesitter.

(or the comment injections for vimscript; I don't think anybody will miss those...)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
 ((codeblock
   (language) @injection.language
   (code) @injection.content)
- (#set! injection.include-children))

comment_data.body: ok
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
 ((codeblock
   (language) @injection.language
   (code) @injection.content)
- (#set! injection.include-children))

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
      <Example bash command to list all Nvim servers: >bash
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9335,25 +9320,27 @@ M.funcs = {
         assigns a random port).
       - Else {address} is the path to a named pipe (except on Windows).
         - If {address} has no slashes ("/") it is treated as the
-          "name" part of a generated path in this format: >
+          "name" part of a generated path in this format: >vim
       	stdpath("run").."/{name}.{pid}.{counter}"
-      <  - If {address} is omitted the name is "nvim". >
-      	:echo serverstart()
+      <  - If {address} is omitted the name is "nvim". >vim
+      	echo serverstart()
+      < >
       	=> /tmp/nvim.bram/oknANW/nvim.15430.5
+      <
 
-      <Example bash command to list all Nvim servers: >
+      <Example bash command to list all Nvim servers: >vim

comment_regular_data.body: And don't forget the static section "2. Matching a pattern in a String" (in `./scripts/gen_eval_files.lua`)!

Random tangent (but don't want to forget): if we're touching `builtin.txt`, we can finally fix the invalid links `|v:_null_{blob,dict,list,string}|` that need excluding in `scripts/gen_help_html.lua`. (Just change the taglink markers to inline code.)

There should only be 2 ts errors by my estimation.

```vim
			echo reduce(0z1122, { acc, val -> 2 * acc + val })
```

and

```vim
			call mkdir($HOME .. "/tmp/foo/bar", "p", 0o700)
```
As long as `scripts/gen_help_html.lua` doesn't complain, we're good!

oh boy, I should have tested this first -- `:h builtin` becomes unusable with all those injections ðŸ˜ž

(Looks nice, tho -- as a slideshow...)

Guess we have a strong incentive to revisit the injection performance improvements now ðŸ˜¬

Regarding the parsing errors: The parser expects the closing `<` marker to be at column 0 here.

(Fixing those could already help performance, though I'm not optimistic.)

> oh boy, I should have tested this first -- `:h builtin` becomes unusable with all those injections ðŸ˜ž
> 
> (Looks nice, tho -- as a slideshow...)
> 
> Guess we have a strong incentive to revisit the injection performance improvements now ðŸ˜¬ 

Oh no, I didn't notice. I hope it isn't too bad.

It's horrible. As in, I need to `kill nvim` if I do `:h builtin` because the editor becomes unresponsive for minutes.

**EDIT** It's something to do with the nvim-treesitter parser or queries; the bundled ones are OK. Just don't do `:InspectTree`...

**EDIT 2** Must be the `comment` parser (again) -- injecting comments into vimscript into vimdoc on that scale is just too much (especially since one comment query uses `#lua-match?`).

Still something to be aware of (nvim-treesitter users _will_ hit this and complain).
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24508 happens to remove many of the codeblocks in builtin.txt, so that should help performance.
Should I wait on this before merging  https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24508 ?

I'm undecided. The perf issues might mean we should sit on this for a bit.

Could you test this and see what it's like for you? I didn't notice any particular slowdown myself.

> I'm undecided. The perf issues might mean we should sit on this for a bit.
> 
> Could you test this and see what it's like for you? I didn't notice any particular slowdown myself.

The perf issues I mention require the `comment` injections from nvim-treesitter; this means you'll have to have both `vim` and `comment` parsers installed using that plugin.

Ah that makes sense as I removed the comment parser.

Why are there even comment injections for vimdoc?
Not for vimdoc, for vimscript (which is injected into vimdoc now).

> Should I wait on this before merging #24508 ?

Depends on how hard it is to rebase this PR (i.e., how much manual work was necessary and has to be repeated). Otherwise there are independent benefits of #24508 (cleaner docs) and no drawbacks, so it would make sense to just go ahead with it already.

(Temporarily disabling the comment->vimscript injections would be the simplest workaround to unblock this.)

I say we just go with this. I'm petrified of having to deal with merge conflicts from this.

Without the comment parser, perf of builtin.txt is just fine from what I can tell.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: docs(builtin): fix and annotate language blocks
